RE, Why doesn't SpaceX just attach the fairing halves to the 1st stage booster? At about 10:40 it came up:

When you think about this, it actually becomes very easy to understand why. I can think of three off the top of my head:

1) Drag.
Regardless of when the fairing releases -- more on that later -- having the two halves attached to the first stage greatly increases it's drag. It would have to release before stage separation, obviously, but regardless of if it's during the boost phase or coast phase, separating them and having them hang off the booster increases it's drag. Even if it would be minimal at the 60-70KM altitude when separation occurs, that's likely still enough that it's going to slow the rocket down. Now, you might think drag is a good thing on re-entry, but...

2) Vehicle stress
Assuming they'd try to close up the fairing somehow, that's going to create significant stresses on the vehicle as it re-enters, and that's not even including the stresses on the joints to close things back up, hold things together, etc. Who knows how that will affect the vehicle as it reenters.

3) Complexity & weight
In addition to the usual complexity of the weight needed for this mechanism, which would reduce payload capacity, etc, the complexity of such a system would add several new possible points of failure to the main mission above what's already involved in simple fairing separation. As I see it, there are basically two possibilities for an integrated fairing: either the entire 2nd stage pops out through a door at the top, or the two halves slide or flip down. For the first, if that 2nd stage makes contact with the side at all, you've lost the mission. If the two halves separate but then don't swing down, or stresses cause one halve to stay up with the connection mechanism, you've lost the mission.

Any way I look at it, I cannot see having the fairing attached working.
